dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: I'd love to hear about your days as a public defender.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Well, those were the early days of my career. It was tough, you know? Long hours, lots of cases, and not much pay.

sentence_annotations.text: It was tough, you know? Long hours, lots of cases, and not much pay.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: It sounds like it was quite a challenging time. Can you tell me more about what drove you to become a public defender in the first place?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Back then, I wanted to make a difference. I felt that everyone deserved representation, no matter their circumstances. It was more about justice than money for me.

sentence_annotations.text: Back then, I wanted to make a difference. I felt that everyone deserved representation, no matter their circumstances. It was more about justice than money for me.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: That must have been hard. So, when did things start to change for you in your career?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Things began to change when I took on a big civil rights case. It was a turning point, really. It drew attention to the issues I was passionate about.

sentence_annotations.text: Things began to change when I took on a big civil rights case.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: I'd love to know how your time as a public defender came to an end.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Eventually, I realized I couldn't keep up with the demands. The workload was immense and I needed a change.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: So, during that big civil rights case, what were some of the core challenges you faced?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: The biggest challenge was dealing with the immense pressure. There was a lot riding on it, and the media attention was overwhelming. We were also up against a well-funded opposition.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: It sounds like handling that pressure was a real test. How did you manage to stay focused and effective during such a stressful time?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: I leaned heavily on my team. We were all in it together, working long nights, digging for every piece of evidence, and ensuring every angle was covered. It was the teamwork that got us through.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: So, after that pivotal civil rights case, how did your career evolve? I'd love to hear about your transition into teaching ethics.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: After that case, I felt a pull towards education. I wanted to impart the lessons I learned, especially about integrity and justice, to the younger generation.

dialogue_turns.text: Reflecting on your teaching career, what has been the most rewarding aspect for you?

dialogue_turns.text: Seeing the students grow and become ethical professionals. It's fulfilling to watch them carry forward the values I held dear throughout my career.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: It sounds like teaching has been a very fulfilling chapter for you. How do you feel looking back on the entirety of your career?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject

dialogue_turns.text: Before we finish, Saul, what would you say is the most important lesson you've learned throughout your life and career?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: I'd say it's the importance of staying true to your principles. No matter the challenges or pressures, if you hold on to your core values, you can navigate through just about anything.
